Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Expectation2: Follow laws and respect others’ rights and public property
Situation2: During a street demonstration, someone urges them to step past a barricade onto restricted city property.
Story: I stood at the edge of the crowd, my stepmother’s words echoing in my mind: “We must always honor our family’s traditions, even when it’s hard.” Our family had always valued standing together, never backing down when we believed in something. Today, that meant joining them at the demonstration, holding signs, and chanting for change. But as the crowd surged forward, someone grabbed my arm and urged me to step past the barricade onto the city’s restricted property. “If you really care, you’ll come with us,” they insisted. My stepbrother’s eyes met mine, full of expectation—our family had always prided itself on courage and unity. Yet, as a citizen, I knew the law was clear: crossing that line was trespassing, disrespecting public property and the rights of others. My heart pounded as I felt the weight of both roles pressing in, each demanding loyalty, each pulling me in a different direction. I hesitated, torn between the family I wanted to belong to and the laws I was raised to respect, unsure which part of myself I could betray.
